. @ayufan I am closing this as a result of our discussion during the call. 
. Reasons why this was declined for community: 
Travis.yml file
We are moving in different direction than Travis. We have difference in architecture that we find simpler.  
Runner: clone repo, run tests & send output to coordinator
Coordinator: get output from runners and show it to user.
Thats why all build scripts should be configured via UI. Its more user friendly and matches current architecture when coordinator does not know anything about repository. 
Runners changes
We should not change runner code until we have a really good reason. No need to add any complexity in runner code. It should be simple lib that run process and submit output via API.
. Thank you
. @williamherry can you please update CHANGELOG too?
. Sorry but we dont support sqlite: 

SQLite shouldn't be used in production (because of mulit-user/multi-process access to DB)
Strange race conditions with SQL
Problems with locking

See discussion for GitLab - https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq/pull/2093
. Old one is expected behaviour. So this looks like a feature/improvement. It makes sense for me if your project requires super-specific ENV so you cant allow other runners to serve your build. So feature looks reasonable. 
But If we want to change behaviour in this way we need next: 
- CHANGELOG entry
- Place in UI where I can see that my project wont be served by shared runners
- Runner UI should say that specific runners lock project from shared runners
- tests for your change
. We introduced specific runners so people can add own laptop/server/vps as runner for own projects only. Ex. I used this to extend build capacity for my fork in one instance. But advantages of specific runners are there to limit where projects can be run are bigger. Still this can be a breaking change for someone. So it should be properly described in UI and has CHANGELOG item

# Checkout preferable version

demisx:
I have Gitlab 5.3 with gitlab-ci 3.0 running. When I run a build the CI_BUILD_REF environment is set to hash. Example:
CI_BUILD_REF=912138fad0beb7763c6f9d439216fe87de300a15
My understanding that it would be set to the name of the branch that triggered the build. If this is not the case, can you please tell me the recommended way to extract the branch name in each build? We need to call different scripts depending on which branch triggered the build.
. @u550ccer NP. I like your suggestion. How about pulling author's email address directly from the commit that is being built in CI? Something like this:
git show  --pretty=tformat:%ae [commit_hash] | head -n 1
I think this would be less error prone.
. @jvanbaarsen @Razer6 Please keep in mind that this PR includes a sample CI build script with email notification being only a small portion of it. The latter can obviously be disabled inside this script. We, personally, found preferred handling of the entire build event within one central script.

. @MichaelSp I looked onto your repo. It's a bit confusing since the commits of your feature are in your master branch. I suggest cleaning up your master branch. I further assume that your branch NewCharts contains all necessary commits. Then I would do the following:
git checkout 32058effd9b246965ade58c0ed303a679b730d7e     # Last commit of from original repo
git checkout -B master                                    # Make this last commit to the new master's HEAD
git pull upstream master                                  # Pull last changes from original repo upstream points to gitlabhq/gitlab-ci, NOT to your repo
git push -f origin master                                 # populate the changes to your repo
Now you can start cleaning the the feature branch. The last Commit on the feature branch is 5c58c1b24841a342f6ee95b715f4c0a0f0ee23d3 - Is this correct?
The I would start with the following:
```
git checkout 5c58c1b24841a342f6ee95b715f4c0a0f0ee23d3       # Checkout last commit
git checkout -B NewCharts                                   # Put this to our feature branch
git rebase master                                           # Start rebasing against master
Now resolve your conflicts
git push -f origin NewCharts
```
Rebasing will apply the feature branch commits on top of your master branch. This will yield conflicts which you have to resolve during rebasing.

. @MichaelSp OK. I'm thinking about a having success and failure scripts that run automatically with an option to limit them to the default branch.
. We've written a proposal for the future of GitLab CI in which the feature is addressed, see http://blog.gitlab.org/gitlab-ci-with-parallel-builds-and-deployments/
In the proposal the deploy is automatic when you deploy to a certain branch. I think that having environmental branches (staging / production) that automatically trigger a deployment is the way forward. Having a manual deployment step is confusing and error prone in my opinion. People forget to deploy their work and people don't know what code is deployed. Automatically deploying on a specific branch you can use merge requests to discuss deploys, it is easy to see the code in production and cherry-picking hotfixes is a breeze.
I'm sad that you put a lot of work in this feature and I don't see a future for it as it is.

tom5760:
When I installed GitLab CI 3.0 yesterday, the list of GitLab projects (at /projects/gitlab) only showed projects I was the owner of, not all projects I was a member of.  Therefore, I could only add projects to GitLab CI for projects I was the owner for in GitLab (unless I'm missing some alternate mechanism for adding projects to GitLab CI).  This is because, by default, the Network.projects() method reads from projects/owned.json by default.
This change makes the opposite behavior: reading from projects.json instead, and allowing the scope parameter to specify reading from projects/owned.json.

u550ccer:
@Colddata,
Thanks very much.  This has been very useful to our group.  
I would suggest adding the following to facilitate mail being sent to the most recent committer upon build failure:
MAIL_TO=$(git log -1 --pretty=tformat:%ae)
. @colddata, Agree - your solution is better.  We also made a few other mods that you might be interested in.  Our build is substantial - so large that adding the text to the email causes a mutt transmission failure.  To deal with that, we write our build output to a file which is then attached to the notification e-mail.  Since our build takes a while, we had requests for notifications when the builds kick off.  So, we added a pre-build e-mail which includes the time that the build started.  Since that could lead to concern that the build hung, we also send emails on both success or failure of the build.  Finally, some of our more active developers were getting confused by which commit kicked off which build.  To handle that, we added the commit message to the e-mails.

Please keep the change in a single MR as small as possible. If you want to contribute a large feature think very hard what the minimum viable change is. Can you split functionality? MarcelEeken:
The problem is not with the relative url behind the main part.
I have my gitlabci installed on gitlab-ci.example.com and when I navigate to a project view it shows all the builds for that project. On https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlab-ci/blob/master/app/views/builds/_build.html.haml#L6 the link to the build_url is called, which generates the exeact url which looks like 
<a href="http://10.0.0.5:9292/projects/4/builds/15">
But if we look at https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlab-ci/blob/master/app/views/builds/_build.html.haml#L15 it calls project_path which generates an url like
<a href="/projects/4?ref=develop">
so it doesn't matter on which domain it is.
I agree that calling _path from inside _url isn't the best solution. But I don't think using _url is also the best solution.
If we look at the documentation at http://guides.rubyonrails.org/routing.html#path-and-url-helpers I think in this case it is best to use _path instead of _url.

I agree with that principle but having a runner environment that isn't static is bad for testing; I don't want the results from one test (which might install software) to influence the result of another (which might need software installed, but doesn't do it, yet it works because an earlier unrelated test installed it). 
These patches would easily allow an unchanging runner environment to be used, much like Travis, without much effort.
